TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi sealed beforefieldinit LayoutEditorPart extends System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.EditorPart
Public NotInheritable Class LayoutEditorPart Inherits EditorPart

Docs.summary: Provides an editor control that enables end users to edit several layout-oriented user interface (UI) properties on an associated control. This class cannot be inherited.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.LayoutEditorPart> class is an editor control that derives from the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.EditorPart> class, and is used to edit properties that affect the layout of an associated <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> or <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.GenericWebPart> control.
Just as there are tool-oriented zones in the Web Parts control set (for details, see the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.ToolZone> class overview), there are tool-oriented part controls (tool parts), and each tool part must reside in a certain type of tool zone. Tool parts in the Web Parts control set have two distinguishing characteristics:
- They are helper controls that enable end users to personalize controls on a Web Parts page.
- They are visible only in certain display modes.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.LayoutEditorPart> control is a tool part that becomes visible only when a Web Parts page is in edit mode, and when a specific <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> control has been selected for editing. The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.LayoutEditorPart> control, like all other <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.EditorPart> controls, resides in an <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.EditorZone> control.
> [!IMPORTANT] > An <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.EditorZone> zone can contain only <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.EditorPart> controls, and <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.EditorPart> controls cannot be placed in any other type of zone.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.LayoutEditorPart> class has a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.LayoutEditorPart.Title%2A> property, which gets or sets the title for a layout control. The class also has a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.LayoutEditorPart.Display%2A> property, which overrides the base property and returns `true`. This means that the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.LayoutEditorPart> control is always visible when the page is in edit mode, even if the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart.AllowEdit%2A> property on the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> control being edited is set to `false`. In other words, users can always edit the properties in a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.LayoutEditorPart> control, even if a specified <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> control cannot be edited by the other <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.EditorPart> controls.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.LayoutEditorPart> class also has two important methods, <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.LayoutEditorPart.ApplyChanges%2A> and <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.LayoutEditorPart.SyncChanges%2A>, which it inherits from the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.EditorPart> class and overrides. The methods are critical because they enable getting and setting the property values between the field values of the editor control and the properties on the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> control being edited.
In most cases, the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.LayoutEditorPart> control should be used in page persistence format by declaring an `<asp:layouteditorpart>` element inside a `<zonetemplate>` element, which is in turn contained by an `<asp:editorzone>` element on a Web page. The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.LayoutEditorPart> control enables end users to edit the following UI properties of a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> control:
- <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.Part.ChromeState%2A>
- <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart.Zone%2A>
- <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart.ZoneIndex%2A>
To edit other properties and behavior of <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> controls, you can use the other <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.EditorPart> controls supplied with the Web Parts control set. These controls include the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.BehaviorEditorPart>, the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.AppearanceEditorPart>, and the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.PropertyGridEditorPart> control. The supplied <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.EditorPart> controls should provide most editing features required to edit <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> controls, but you can also create a custom editor control by inheriting from the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.EditorPart> class. For a code example, see the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.EditorPart> class overview.
> [!NOTE] > To improve accessibility, the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.LayoutEditorPart> control is rendered within a `<fieldset>` element. The `<fieldset>` element groups the related set of controls used for editing in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.LayoutEditorPart> control, and it facilitates tabbed navigation among those controls for both visual user agents (such as ordinary Web browsers) and speech-oriented user agents (such as screen-reading software).
## Accessibility The markup rendered by default for this control might not conform to accessibility standards such as the Web Content Accessibility Guidelines 1.0 (WCAG) priority 1 guidelines. For details about accessibility support for this control, see [ASP.NET Controls and Accessibility](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/847a37e3-ce20-41da-b0d3-7dfb0fdae9a0).
## Examples The following code example demonstrates how to declare a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.LayoutEditorPart> control on a Web page, and enable it to edit several UI properties of a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> control. The code example has three parts:
- A user control that enables you to change display modes on a Web Parts page.
- A Web page that contains an <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.EditorZone> control and a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.LayoutEditorPart> control, which is used to edit the layout properties of a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.BulletedList> control.
- An explanation of how the example works when you load the page in a browser.
The first part of this code example is the user control that enables users to change display modes on a Web page. For details about display modes and a description of the source code in this control, see [Walkthrough: Changing Display Modes on a Web Parts Page](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/24e42f74-82dc-4c13-8574-130398985fc0).
[!code-aspx-csharp[WebParts_LayoutEditorPart_Overview#5](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_WebNet/WebParts_LayoutEditorPart_Overview/CS/DisplayModeMenuCS.ascx#5)] [!code-aspx-vb[WebParts_LayoutEditorPart_Overview#5](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_WebNet/WebParts_LayoutEditorPart_Overview/VB/DisplayModeMenuVB.ascx#5)]
The second part of the code example is the Web page. It contains a declarative reference to an <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.EditorZone> control, with a child `<zonetemplate>` element that contains declarative references to a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.LayoutEditorPart> control. Note that the page also contains a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.BulletedList> control that is bound to the Pubs database; because this control resides in a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartZone> zone, it functions as a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> control that can be edited by the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.LayoutEditorPart> control.
[!code-aspx-csharp[WebParts_LayoutEditorPart_Overview#1](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_WebNet/WebParts_LayoutEditorPart_Overview/CS/layouteditorpartcs.aspx#1)] [!code-aspx-vb[WebParts_LayoutEditorPart_Overview#1](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_WebNet/WebParts_LayoutEditorPart_Overview/VB/layouteditorpartvb.aspx#1)]
When you load the page in a browser, you can select **Edit Mode** in the **Display Mode** drop-down list control to switch to edit mode. You can click the verbs menu (the downward arrow) in the title bar of the **Author List WebPart** control, and click **Edit** to begin editing. When the editing UI is visible, you can see the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.LayoutEditorPart> control, and a button and text box positioned above it. If you make some changes in the editing UI and click the **Apply** button, you can use the **Display Mode** drop-down list control to return the page to browse mode and see the full effect of the editing changes.

Docs.summary: Creates a new instance of the class.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.LayoutEditorPart.%23ctor%2A> constructor is a default; no constructor is declared in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.LayoutEditorPart> class and hence no special tasks are carried out when a new instance of the class is created.
Normally you do not need to use the constructor, because you can add a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.LayoutEditorPart> control to a page declaratively at design time. However, if you need to add a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.LayoutEditorPart> control programmatically for some reason, you can use the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.LayoutEditorPart.%23ctor%2A> constructor.

MemberSignature.Value: public override bool ApplyChanges ();
.method public hidebysig virtual instance bool ApplyChanges() cil managed
Public Overrides Function ApplyChanges () As Boolean
public: override bool ApplyChanges();
override this.ApplyChanges : unit -> bool

Docs.summary: Saves the values from a control to the corresponding properties in the associated control.
Docs.returns: if the action of saving values from the control to the control is successful; otherwise (if an error occurs), .

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.LayoutEditorPart.ApplyChanges%2A> method is a critical method on a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.LayoutEditorPart> control. The method's purpose is to save the values a user has set on a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.LayoutEditorPart> control to the corresponding properties in the associated <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> control. The associated control is referenced in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.LayoutEditorPart> control's inherited <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.EditorPart.WebPartToEdit%2A> property.
> [!IMPORTANT] > You cannot call the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.LayoutEditorPart.ApplyChanges%2A> method from your own code. However, if you need more programmatic control over the process of editing various <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> control properties than the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.LayoutEditorPart> control provides, you can create a custom <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.EditorPart> control and provide your own implementation of this method. For an example, see the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.EditorPart.ApplyChanges%2A?displayProperty=nameWithType> method.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.LayoutEditorPart.ApplyChanges%2A> method attempts to set the following properties on the associated <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> control:
- <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart.ChromeState%2A>
- <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart.Zone%2A>
- <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart.ZoneIndex%2A>
The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.LayoutEditorPart.ApplyChanges%2A> method is called when the user clicks a button representing an OK or an apply verb in the editing user interface (UI).

Docs.exception: An error occurred when setting the value of the property on the associated control.

Docs.summary: Overrides the base property inherited from the control to hide the property from designers and prevent it from being affected by themes.
Docs.value: A string that contains the ID of the control that receives the default focus in a control.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Though it is public, this property is used for default rendering of this control and is not intended to be called from developer code.
This property cannot be set by themes or style sheet themes. For more information, see <xref:System.Web.UI.ThemeableAttribute> and [ASP.NET Themes and Skins](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/5df3ebbd-d46c-4502-9406-02f9df4ef2c3).

.property instance bool Display
Public Overrides ReadOnly Property Display As Boolean
public: virtual property bool Display { bool get(); };
member this.Display : bool

Docs.summary: Gets a value that indicates whether a control should be displayed when its associated control is in edit mode.
Docs.value: A Boolean value that indicates whether the control should be displayed.

remarks.format: ## Remarks The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.LayoutEditorPart.Display%2A> property returns `true` even if the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart.AllowEdit%2A> property is `false` on the associated <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> control. This is so that the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.LayoutEditorPart> control can always be available in edit mode, even when a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> control cannot be edited by the other <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.EditorPart> controls.

public override void SyncChanges ();
.method public hidebysig virtual instance void SyncChanges() cil managed
Public Overrides Sub SyncChanges ()
public: override void SyncChanges();
override this.SyncChanges : unit -> unit

Docs.summary: Retrieves the property values from a control and assigns them to the associated control.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.LayoutEditorPart.SyncChanges%2A> method is a critical method on a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.LayoutEditorPart> control. It implements the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.EditorPart.SyncChanges%2A> method from the base class, retrieves the current values from the associated <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> control, and updates the child controls in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.LayoutEditorPart> control with those values so a user can edit them.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.LayoutEditorPart.SyncChanges%2A> method is called whenever the values in the associated <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> control might have changed. For a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.LayoutEditorPart> control, the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.EditorZoneBase> zone that contains the control calls the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.LayoutEditorPart.SyncChanges%2A> method immediately after calling the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.LayoutEditorPart.ApplyChanges%2A> method, so that the values in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.LayoutEditorPart> control are always synchronized with the values in the associated <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> control. Another case where the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.LayoutEditorPart.SyncChanges%2A> method is called is when a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> control is initially entering edit mode.

block.para: Although you can call the method from your code, it is not necessary to do so. The Web Parts control set calls this method and the method at the proper times in the editing process to keep editing controls synchronized with their associated controls.

MemberSignature.Value: public override string Title { get; set; }
.property instance string Title
Public Overrides Property Title As String
public: virtual property System::String ^ Title { System::String ^ get(); void set(System::String ^ value); };
member this.Title : string with get, set

Docs.summary: Gets or sets a title for the editor control.
Docs.value: A string that is used as the title of the control. The default value is a calculated control name supplied by the Web Parts control set.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.LayoutEditorPart.Title%2A> property value is displayed in the title bar of a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.LayoutEditorPart> control when the control is visible in edit mode. When the control is declared in a page, you can set a value for the `Title` attribute. If you do not supply a value for the title, a culture-specific default value is used to describe the properties that this control allows users to edit.
## Examples This code example demonstrates how to use the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.LayoutEditorPart.Title%2A> property of a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.LayoutEditorPart> control. For the full code required to run the example, see the Example section of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.LayoutEditorPart> class overview.
The following code shows how to set the title on a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.LayoutEditorPart> control declaratively in a Web page.
[!code-aspx-csharp[WebParts_LayoutEditorPart_Overview#2](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_WebNet/WebParts_LayoutEditorPart_Overview/CS/layouteditorpartcs.aspx#2)] [!code-aspx-vb[WebParts_LayoutEditorPart_Overview#2](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_WebNet/WebParts_LayoutEditorPart_Overview/VB/layouteditorpartvb.aspx#2)]
The next part of the code example shows how to set the value of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.LayoutEditorPart.Title%2A> property programmatically.
[!code-csharp[WebParts_LayoutEditorPart_Overview#3](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_WebNet/WebParts_LayoutEditorPart_Overview/CS/layouteditorpartcs.aspx#3)] [!code-vb[WebParts_LayoutEditorPart_Overview#3](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_WebNet/WebParts_LayoutEditorPart_Overview/VB/layouteditorpartvb.aspx#3)]
When you load the page in a browser, you can select **Edit Mode** in the **Display Mode** drop-down list control to switch to edit mode. You can click the verbs menu (the downward arrow) in the title bar of the **Author List WebPart** control, and click **Edit** to begin editing. When the editing user interface (UI) is visible, you can see the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.LayoutEditorPart> control, and a button and text box positioned above it. Note that the title of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.LayoutEditorPart> control is the value assigned to it in the declarative markup of the Web page. If you enter some text in the text box next to the **Update EditorPart Title** button, and then click the button, the title for the control is updated.
